deliberation: Noted the extended use of family and commercial law imagery. Detected two distinct but related metaphors: (1) Israel/Zion as a divorced wife ('bill of divorce of your mother'), (2) Israel as children sold to a creditor / sold for their sins. I treat these as two separate figurative expressions because they draw on different legal domains (marriage vs. debt-slavery), even though both explain exile.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵי זֶה סֵפֶר כְּרִיתוּת אִמְּכֶם אֲשֶׁר שִׁלַּחְתִּיהָ
instances.english_text: Where is the bill of divorce of your mother whom I dismissed?
target: Zion/Jerusalem being sent into exile and feeling abandoned by God
Israel’s covenant relationship and perceived rejection
Theological understanding of exile and covenant status
vehicle: A wife’s bill of divorce issued by a husband who sends her away
Legal document of marital separation in ancient Israelite law
Ancient Near Eastern family-law institution
ground: Formal termination and sending away from a covenantal relationship
Separation, rejection, and legal severing of obligations
Relational-legal status between parties in a covenant/bond
posture: Denying that such a divine divorce document exists
Defensive rhetorical question challenging Israel’s assumptions
Prophetic disputation speech correcting theology of abandonment
instances.explanation: God depicts Zion/Israel as a divorced mother who would have a ‘bill of divorce’ if God had truly cast her off; by asking for this document and implying it does not exist, the prophet uses marital-divorce imagery to argue that exile is not a final, legal severing of the relationship.

instances.hebrew_text: אוֹ מִי מִנּוֹשַׁי אֲשֶׁר־מָכַרְתִּי אֶתְכֶם לוֹ ... הֵן בַּעֲוֺנֹתֵיכֶם נִמְכַּרְתֶּם
instances.english_text: And which of My creditors was it to whom I sold you off? You were only sold off for your sins,
target: Israel’s experience of subjugation and exile among the nations
The people’s loss of freedom and suffering under foreign powers
Historical-political reality of judgment (conquest and exile)
vehicle: Children being sold off to satisfy a father’s debts to a creditor
Commercial sale into debt-slavery
Ancient Near Eastern economic/legal practice
ground: Being handed over into another’s control as a consequence of liability
Loss of freedom due to an outstanding, incurred obligation
Causal link between wrongdoing and enforced servitude
posture: Reframing exile as the result of Israel’s own sins rather than divine insolvency
Corrective, accusatory explanation of the cause of judgment
Prophetic theodicy defending God’s honor and justice
instances.explanation: God rejects the idea that He had to sell Israel to a creditor, and instead uses the image of a debt-sale to say, ‘You were sold because of your own iniquities,’ treating sin as a kind of debt that leads to being sold into servitude.

deliberation: Observed several rhetorical questions and descriptions of divine power over sea and rivers. Those cosmic acts can be taken as literal miracles (Exodus motif) rather than figurative. The clearest figurative element is the idiom of God’s ‘arm/hand being too short’ as a metaphor for insufficient power to redeem.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲקָצוֹר קָצְרָה יָדִי מִפְּדוּת וְאִם־אֵין־בִּי כֹחַ לְהַצִּיל
instances.english_text: Is my arm, then, too short to rescue, have I not the power to save?
target: YHWH’s ability to redeem and save Israel from distress
Divine power and effectiveness in deliverance
Theological perception of God’s might
vehicle: A person whose arm is too short to reach and rescue someone
Physical limitation of bodily reach or strength
Human bodily experience of restricted capability
ground: Inability to reach someone in need because one’s arm cannot extend far enough
Insufficiency of power or reach to accomplish a rescue
Perceived limitation or weakness in effective action
posture: Rejecting any suggestion that God’s power is limited or ineffective
Rhetorical challenge that exposes Israel’s lack of trust
Prophetic reassurance of divine omnipotence
instances.explanation: God’s ‘arm’ is used metaphorically for His saving power, and the idea of it being ‘too short’ pictures Him as physically unable to reach, an image He denies in order to affirm His undiminished power to redeem.

deliberation: The verse portrays the heavens as if they could be clothed, specifically in blackness and sackcloth—mourning garments. This is a personification/metaphor complex describing cosmic mourning and judgment through the image of dressing the sky.

instances.hebrew_text: אַלְבִּישׁ שָׁמַיִם קַדְרוּת וְשַׂק אָשִׂים כְּסוּתָם
instances.english_text: I clothe the skies in blackness and make their raiment sackcloth.
target: The altered state of the cosmos under divine judgment (darkened heavens)
Cosmic signs of mourning/doom accompanying God’s actions
Eschatological or historical judgment scenarios
vehicle: A person being dressed in black, sackcloth garments of mourning
Ritual clothing that signifies grief and humiliation
Human funerary and penitential practice
ground: Outward dark and rough clothing as a visible sign of inner mourning and distress
Association of blackness and sackcloth with grief, repentance, and calamity
External manifestation of sorrow or judgment
posture: Portraying God as sovereignly imposing mourning on the cosmos
Threatening image intended to evoke awe and fear
Prophetic depiction of judgment in vivid, symbolic terms
instances.explanation: The heavens are personified as if they could wear clothes, and God ‘dresses’ them in blackness and sackcloth to depict cosmic mourning and the gloom of judgment.

deliberation: Looked for non-literal uses related to speech and hearing. The phrase ‘to sustain the weary with a word’ treats speech as something that gives physical support, and ‘He awakens my ear’ personifies the ear as a sleeper being roused for instruction. These are distinct figurative expressions.

instances.english_text: To know how to speak timely words to the weary [lit. ‘to sustain the weary with a word’].
target: The effect of the servant’s prophetic speech on discouraged people
Encouragement and strengthening of the weary
Pastoral/prophetic ministry to the afflicted
vehicle: Physically sustaining or propping up a tired person
Giving material support or nourishment to the exhausted
Concrete acts of upholding someone’s body
ground: Providing strength, stability, and renewed capacity to someone faltering
Restoring capacity to continue under burden
Turning weakness into renewed endurance
posture: Highlighting the constructive, life-supporting power of prophetic speech
Affirming the servant’s role as a comforter of the weary
Positive, nurturing depiction of the mission
instances.explanation: The verse pictures the servant’s ‘word’ as if it were a physical support that can ‘sustain’ a weary person, equating spoken encouragement with tangible strengthening.

instances.hebrew_text: יָעִיר בַּבֹּקֶר בַּבֹּקֶר יָעִיר לִי אֹזֶן לִשְׁמֹעַ כַּלִּמּוּדִים
instances.english_text: Morning by morning, He rouses me, rousing my ear to give heed like disciples.
target: The servant’s receptivity and obedience to divine instruction
Inner readiness to listen and learn from God
Prophetic consciousness
vehicle: A sleeper being awakened and an ear being roused to alertness
Physical waking from sleep and the opening of the senses
Daily routine of rising to hear instruction
ground: Movement from unresponsiveness to attentiveness
Transition from dormancy to active listening and learning
Regular, disciplined responsiveness to a teacher’s call
posture: Emphasizing God’s initiative in preparing the servant to listen
Humble portrayal of the servant as a taught disciple
Devotional, submissive stance toward divine teaching
instances.explanation: The ‘ear’ is personified as something that can be ‘roused’ each morning, picturing the servant’s readiness to hear God as a daily awakening from sleep.

deliberation: Here the central non-literal phrase is ‘the Lord GOD opened my ears’, an idiomatic metaphor for enabling obedient listening. The rest of the verse (‘I did not rebel, I did not turn back’) is straightforwardly literal.

instances.english_text: My Sovereign GOD opened my ears,
target: The servant’s capacity and willingness to hear and obey God
Moral and spiritual receptivity
Interior disposition of obedience
vehicle: Physically opening an ear that had been closed or stopped
Unblocking a sensory organ so that sound can enter
Concrete act of removing a barrier to hearing
ground: Removing impediments to perception so that messages can be received
Transition from deafness/unresponsiveness to hearing/obedience
Enablement for genuine attentiveness
posture: Confessing dependence on God for obedient listening
Testimonial acknowledgment of divine initiative
Submissive attitude toward God’s word
instances.explanation: ‘Opening the ear’ is an idiomatic metaphor for making someone truly attentive and obedient, depicting the servant’s obedience as the result of God’s work in unstopping his ears.

deliberation: Considered whether the descriptions of beatings, hair-plucking, shame, and spitting might be figurative. They appear as concrete acts of abuse voluntarily endured by the servant, without clear metaphorical transfers (no ‘like/as’ comparison, no non-literal domains being mapped). Thus I take the language as primarily literal depiction of suffering, not figurative.

Identified a conventional Hebrew simile/idiom: ‘I have set my face like flint.’ ‘Face’ stands for inner resolve and ‘flint’ represents hardness; the explicit כ (‘like’) marks this as a simile. The rest (help, shame, disgrace) can be read literally.

instances.english_text: Therefore I have set my face like flint,
target: The servant’s inner determination to endure opposition without shame
Moral courage and steadfastness under trial
Psychological/spiritual resilience
vehicle: A piece of flint stone that is extremely hard and unyielding
A hard, sharp stone used for cutting or striking
Physical object characterized by toughness
ground: Unyielding hardness in the face of pressure or blows
Inability to be easily scratched, deformed, or turned aside
Steadfast resistance to attempts to break or change it
posture: Resolute, confident commitment rooted in trust in God’s help
Self-description meant to inspire and defend the servant’s stance
Prophetic self-presentation as unwaveringly obedient
instances.explanation: The servant’s ‘face’ represents his resolve, and by comparing it to flint he depicts his determination as hard, unyielding, and resistant to shame or intimidation.

deliberation: The verse uses a legal/courtroom frame: ‘my Vindicator’, ‘who will contend with me’, ‘let us stand up together’, ‘who is the master of my lawsuit’. This treats the conflict as a lawsuit in which God is the legal defender. I treat the forensic frame as one extended metaphor rather than splitting each legal phrase.

instances.hebrew_text: קָרוֹב מַצְדִּיקִי מִי־יָרִיב אִתִּי נַעַמְדָה יָּחַד מִי־בַעַל מִשְׁפָּטִי יִגַּשׁ אֵלָי
instances.english_text: My Vindicator is at hand—Who dares contend with me? Let us stand up together! Who would be my opponent? Let them approach me!
target: The dispute between the servant and his opponents, and its outcome
The servant’s innocence and divine vindication in conflict
Spiritual-moral controversy surrounding the servant’s mission
vehicle: A lawsuit in which a vindicating advocate stands near the accused, facing an adversary in court
Forensic proceedings with plaintiff, defendant, and legal counsel
Ancient legal setting where cases are argued and judgments rendered
ground: Public adjudication of right and wrong before an authoritative judge
Securing a favorable verdict through the support of a powerful advocate
Confronting an accuser in a structured setting where truth is tested
posture: Bold challenge to adversaries on the basis of God’s nearness as advocate
Confident, confrontational rhetoric grounded in expected vindication
Prophetic assurance that God will declare the servant in the right
instances.explanation: The servant frames his conflict with opponents as a lawsuit, calling God ‘my Vindicator’ and inviting adversaries to ‘stand’ and ‘approach’ like litigants in court, thus using forensic metaphor to express confidence in divine justification.

deliberation: The climactic image compares the servant’s opponents to a garment that wears out and is eaten by moths. This is an explicit simile, with further extension (‘the moth will consume them’) continuing the same clothing-decay picture.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן כֻּלָּם כַּבֶּגֶד יִבְלוּ עָשׁ יֹאכְלֵם
instances.english_text: They shall all wear out like a garment, the moth shall consume them.
target: The fate of the servant’s accusers and adversaries
The eventual disappearance and futility of opposition to God’s servant
Human opponents under divine judgment
vehicle: A garment that becomes threadbare and is eaten by moths over time
Old clothing subject to decay and insect damage
Perishable fabric in everyday life
ground: Gradual but inevitable decay ending in uselessness and disappearance
Fragility and impermanence of material things exposed to corrosive forces
The ease with which seemingly sturdy items can be undone
posture: Reassuring the servant (and hearers) that opposition is temporary
Undercutting the apparent strength of enemies with an image of fragility
Prophetic confidence in the transience of human opposition
instances.explanation: The accusers are likened to a garment that inevitably wears out and is destroyed by moths, highlighting the temporary and fragile nature of their power in contrast to God’s help.

deliberation: Saw several layered figures: ‘walking in darkness’ for experiencing trouble and lack of guidance; ‘trust in the name of YHWH’ as metonymy (name for person/character); and ‘rely/lean on his God’ as a metaphor of physical leaning for spiritual dependence. Treated these three as distinct but closely related expressions.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲשֶׁר הָלַךְ חֲשֵׁכִים וְאֵין נֹגַהּ לוֹ
instances.english_text: Though walking in darkness and having no light,
target: The believer’s experience of distress, confusion, or lack of visible guidance
Periods of spiritual or existential obscurity for God-fearers
Human life-situation under trial
vehicle: A traveler walking in deep darkness with no light shining for them
Physical movement along a path without illumination
Perilous navigation in the night
ground: Uncertainty, vulnerability, and danger when one cannot see the way
Inability to discern direction or obstacles ahead
Need for trust when external visual aids are absent
posture: Realistically acknowledging that even God-fearers may pass through dark experiences
Setting the stage for an exhortation to trust despite lack of clarity
Pastoral recognition of the difficulty of faith without visible signs
instances.explanation: The condition of a God-fearing person is pictured as ‘walking in darkness’—a metaphor for living through confusing, distressing circumstances without evident guidance.

instances.english_text: Let them trust in the name of GOD,
target: YHWH Himself—His character, presence, and reliability
The object of the believer’s faith
Divine identity as trusted refuge
vehicle: The ‘name’ of YHWH as spoken and invoked
Linguistic designation representing a person
Covenantal name revealed to Israel
ground: A name stands for and evokes the person it designates
Calling on or trusting a name is functionally trusting the person behind it
The reputation and character summarized under a name
posture: Directing faith toward God’s revealed character and reputation
Encouraging reliance on God even when only His ‘name’ is heard, not seen
Cultivating trust grounded in God’s covenantal self-disclosure
instances.explanation: ‘Name’ here stands metonymically for God Himself and His character; to trust in the name of YHWH is to trust in YHWH as He has revealed Himself.

target: The believer’s act of depending on God for support and stability
Faith as practical dependence on God
Spiritual posture of trust
vehicle: A person leaning on another or on a staff for support
Physical act of resting one’s weight on something stronger
Concrete bodily dependence on a support structure
ground: Transferring weight to something trusted to hold you up
Inability to stand securely without external support
Confidence that the one leaned on will not give way
posture: Exhortative, inviting intimate and total dependence on God
Encouraging an embodied image of trust (leaning) rather than mere assent
Pastoral appeal to rely on God in the midst of darkness
instances.explanation: Relying on God is portrayed as physically ‘leaning’ on Him, using the image of bodily dependence to describe spiritual trust.

deliberation: The people are described as ‘kindlers of fire’ who ‘gird’ themselves with firebrands and are told ironically to ‘walk in the light of your fire’. This is a metaphor for self-made guidance and schemes opposed to trusting God, with strong ironic tone. I treat the fire-/light imagery including the ironic imperative as one extended figurative expression.

instances.hebrew_text: הֵן כֻּלְּכֶם קֹדְחֵי אֵשׁ מְאַזְּרֵי זִיקוֹת לְכוּ בְּאוּר אֶשְׁכֶם וּבְזִיקוֹת בִּעַרְתֶּם
instances.english_text: But you are all kindlers of fire, girding on firebrands. Walk by the blaze of your fire, by the brands that you have lit!
target: The people’s self-reliant, rebellious plans and sources of guidance apart from God
Human attempts to create their own ‘light’ and security
Religious and ethical self-direction in defiance of divine instruction
vehicle: People who ignite their own fires, strap on firebrands, and walk by the light of those flames
Making and carrying artificial light sources in the dark
Controlling and trusting man-made fire
ground: Generating one’s own illumination instead of receiving light from another source
Depending on something one has produced, which can also burn and harm
Short-lived, dangerous brilliance that contrasts with stable, safe light
posture: Ironic and sardonic invitation to pursue self-made ‘light’ as a path to ruin
Prophetic warning that self-directed plans will end in torment
Judgmental stance exposing the folly of rejecting God’s guidance
instances.explanation: By calling them ‘kindlers of fire’ and telling them to walk in the light of their own flames, the prophet metaphorically portrays their self-made guidance and schemes as a dangerous, man-made fire, using irony to highlight that this path will bring them pain.
